comparison.name: XML
comparison.description: The XML InfoSets should be canonicalized and compared.

comparison.name: Fragment
comparison.description: A 'fragment' refers to an XML based instance which has multiple top-level elements and NO XML declaration. The comparator for this should simply wrap the entire fragment in a container element and perform XML comparison.

comparison.name: Text
comparison.description: Each line of non-whitespace text should match. New-line sequences may vary and should be neutralized. Due to issues with the XML serialization of certain characters (e.g. '<'), it is not possible to simply compare the actual and expected results. Rather (as is the case with the 'Fragment' comparator) the test harness should convert the results into valid XML (by adding a container element) and perform comparison on the XML canonicalized versions of the results.

comparison.name: Ignore
comparison.description: Only the presence/absence of this file is significant, not its content.

comparison.name: Inspect
comparison.description: Automated comparison is not possible. the output should be inspected by a human.

role.name: principal-data
role.description: This is the source that is handed in to the processor as the initial input sequence, setting the "evaluation context" as described in XQuery chapter 2.

role.name: supplemental-data
role.description: These are sources that may be read by functions such as fn:document() as the query is evaluated.

role.name: schema
role.description: These are schema definitions that may be referenced by sources or in the query.

role.name: dtd
role.description: These are dtd definitions that may be referenced by sources or in the query.

role.name: stopwords
role.description: This is a list of stop words, one per line, to indicate the desired set of stop words referenced by the query.

role.name: thesaurus
role.description: This is a thesaurus, represented in XML according to the thesaurus.xsd schema, to indicate the desired thesaurus information in a thesaurus referenced by the query.

role.name: stemming-dictionary
role.description: This is a list of stemming relationships, one per line, where each whitespace-separated token on the line should stem to the first token on the line. It is used to indicate the desired stemming behaviour expected by the query.

role.name: principal
role.description: This is an output (either text or XML) that will contain the query results. If the processor invocation sequence accepts a filename for results, this name may be passed, possibly prefixed by a partial directory path to allow storage of the results in a separate directory tree.

role.name: console-log
role.description: This is an output (text file tagged .log) that will contain the captured "console" output for a command-line invocation, or equivalent messages from a harness. The main goal is to capture error messages that came from the processor.
role.note: A test lab may choose to capture console output for every test case, in which case the presence of this element is a signal that the console log of this test contains messages that are significant to the pass/fail determination.

scenario.name: standard
scenario.description: A query this is expected to produce valid results. Principal input should always be specified, even if the query doesn't have any PathExpr.

scenario.name: parse-error
scenario.description: A query this is expected to raise a parsing/syntax error at query parse time. Principal input should always be specified, even if the query doesn't have any PathExpr.

scenario.name: runtime-error
scenario.description: A query this is expected to raise a runtime error at query parse time. Runtime errors in this case include those raised by static typing rules. Principal input should always be specified, even if the query doesn't have any PathExpr.

implementation-defined-item.name: expressionUnicode
implementation-defined-item.description: The version of Unicode that is used to construct expressions.

implementation-defined-item.name: collations
implementation-defined-item.description: The statically-known collations.

implementation-defined-item.name: implicitTimezone
implementation-defined-item.description: The implicit timezone.

implementation-defined-item.name: warningsMethod
implementation-defined-item.description: The circumstances in which warnings are raised, and the ways in which warnings are handled.

implementation-defined-item.name: errorsMethod
implementation-defined-item.description: The method by which errors are reported to the external processing environment.

implementation-defined-item.name: XMLVersion
implementation-defined-item.description: Whether the implementation is based on the rules of [XML 1.0] and [XML Names] or the rules of [XML 1.1] and [XML Names 1.1]. One of these sets of rules must be applied consistently by all aspects of the implementation.

implementation-defined-item.name: overwrittenContextComponents
implementation-defined-item.description: Any components of the static context or dynamic context that are overwritten or augmented by the implementation.

implementation-defined-item.name: axes
implementation-defined-item.description: Which of the optional axes are supported by the implementation, if the Full-Axis Feature is not supported.

implementation-defined-item.name: defaultOrderEmpty
implementation-defined-item.description: The default handling of empty sequences returned by an ordering key (sortspec) in an order by clause (empty least or empty greatest).

implementation-defined-item.name: pragmas
implementation-defined-item.description: The names and semantics of any extension expressions (pragmas) recognized by the implementation.

implementation-defined-item.name: optionDeclarations
implementation-defined-item.description: The names and semantics of any option declarations recognized by the implementation.

implementation-defined-item.name: externalFunctionProtocols
implementation-defined-item.description: Protocols (if any) by which parameters can be passed to an external function, and the result of the function can returned to the invoking query.

implementation-defined-item.name: moduleLocationHints
implementation-defined-item.description: The process by which the specific modules to be imported by a module import are identified, if the Module Feature is supported (includes processing of location hints, if any.)

implementation-defined-item.name: staticTypingExtensions
implementation-defined-item.description: Any static typing extensions supported by the implementation, if the Static Typing Feature is supported.

implementation-defined-item.name: serializationInvocation
implementation-defined-item.description: The means by which serialization is invoked, if the Serialization Feature is supported.

implementation-defined-item.name: serializationDefaults
implementation-defined-item.description: The default values for the byte-order-mark, encoding, media-type, normalization-form, omit-xml-declaration, standalone, and version parameters, if the Serialization Feature is supported.

implementation-defined-item.name: externalFunctionCall
implementation-defined-item.description: The result of an unsuccessful call to an external function (for example, if the function implementation cannot be found or does not return a value of the declared type).

implementation-defined-item.name: limits
implementation-defined-item.description: Limits on ranges of values for various data types, as enumerated in 5.3 Data Model Conformance.

implementation-defined-item.name: traceDestination
implementation-defined-item.description: The destination of the trace output is implementation-defined. See 4 The Trace Function.

implementation-defined-item.name: integerOperations
implementation-defined-item.description: For xs:integer operations, implementations that support limited-precision integer operations must either raise an error [err:FOAR0002] or provide an implementation-defined mechanism that allows users to choose between raising an error and returning a result that is modulo the largest representable integer value. See 6.2 Operators on Numeric Values.

implementation-defined-item.name: decimalDigits
implementation-defined-item.description: For xs:decimal values the number of digits of precision returned by the numeric operators is implementation-defined. See 6.2 Operators on Numeric Values. See also 17.1.3.3 Casting to xs:decimal and 17.1.3.4 Casting to xs:integer.

implementation-defined-item.name: roundOrTruncate
implementation-defined-item.description: If the number of digits in the result exceeds the number of digits that the implementation supports, the result is truncated or rounded in an implementation-defined manner. See 6.2 Operators on Numeric Values. See also 17.1.3.3 Casting to xs:decimal and 17.1.3.4 Casting to xs:integer.

implementation-defined-item.name: Unicode
implementation-defined-item.description: It is implementation-defined which version of Unicode is supported by the features defined in this specification, but it is recommended that the most recent version of Unicode be used. See 7.1 String Types.

implementation-defined-item.name: normalizationForms
implementation-defined-item.description: For 7.4.6 fn:normalize-unicode, conforming implementations must support normalization form "NFC" and may support normalization forms "NFD", "NFKC", "NFKD", "FULLY-NORMALIZED". They may also support other normalization forms with implementation-defined semantics.

implementation-defined-item.name: collationUnits
implementation-defined-item.description: The ability to decompose strings into collation units suitable for substring matching is an implementation-defined property of a collation. See 7.5 Functions Based on Substring Matching.

implementation-defined-item.name: secondsDigits
implementation-defined-item.description: All minimally conforming processors must support year values with a minimum of 4 digits (i.e., YYYY) and a minimum fractional second precision of 1 millisecond or three digits (i.e., s.sss). However, conforming processors may set larger implementation-defined limits on the maximum number of digits they support in these two situations. See 10.1.1 Limits and Precision.

implementation-defined-item.name: stringToDecimal
implementation-defined-item.description: The result of casting a string to xs:decimal, when the resulting value is not too large or too small but nevertheless has too many decimal digits to be accurately represented, is implementation-defined. See 17.1.1 Casting from xs:string and xs:untypedAtomic.

implementation-defined-item.name: docProcessing
implementation-defined-item.description: Various aspects of the processing provided by 15.5.4 fn:doc are implementation-defined. Implementations may provide external configuration options that allow any aspect of the processing to be controlled by the user.

implementation-defined-item.name: weakenStable
implementation-defined-item.description: The manner in which implementations provide options to weaken the stable characteristic of 15.5.6 fn:collection and 15.5.4 fn:doc are implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: additionalTypes
implementation-defined-item.description: Support for additional user-defined or implementation-defined types is implementation-defined. (See 2.6.1 Representation of Types)

implementation-defined-item.name: undefinedProperties
implementation-defined-item.description: Some typed values in the data model are undefined. Attempting to access an undefined property is always an error. Behavior in these cases is implementation-defined and the host language is responsible for determining the result. (See 5 Accessors)

implementation-defined-item.name: sequenceNormalization
implementation-defined-item.description: For any implementation-defined output method, it is implementation-defined whether sequence normalization process takes place. (See 2 Sequence Normalization)

implementation-defined-item.name: outputMethods
implementation-defined-item.description: If the namespace URI is non-null for the method serialization parameter, then the parameter specifies an implementation-defined output method. (See 3 Serialization Parameters)

implementation-defined-item.name: normalizationFormBehavior
implementation-defined-item.description: If the value of the normalization-form form parameter is not NFC, NFD, NFKC, NFKD, fully-normalized, or none then the meaning of the value and it's effect is implementation-defined. (See 4 Phases of Serialization)

implementation-defined-item.name: additionalParams
implementation-defined-item.description: The effect of additional serialization parameters on the output of the serializer, where the name of such a parameter must be namespace-qualified, is implementation-defined or implementation-dependent. The extent of this effect on the output must not override the provisions of this specification. (See 3 Serialization Parameters)

implementation-defined-item.name: encodingPhase
implementation-defined-item.description: The effect of providing an option that allows the encoding phase to be skipped, so that the result of serialization is a stream of Unicode characters, is implementation-defined. The serializer is not required to support such an option. (See 4 Phases of Serialization)

implementation-defined-item.name: CDATASerialization
implementation-defined-item.description: An serializer may provide an implementation-defined mechanism to place CDATA sections in the result tree. (See 5.1.4 XML Output Method: the cdata-section-elements Parameter)

implementation-defined-item.name: Tokenization
implementation-defined-item.description: Tokenization, including the definition of the term "tokens", SHOULD be implementation-defined. Implementations SHOULD expose the rules and sample results of tokenization as much as possible to enable users to predict and interpret the results of tokenization. Tokenization is defined more formally in 4.1 Tokenization.

implementation-defined-item.name: token
implementation-defined-item.description: A token is a non-empty sequence of characters returned by a tokenizer as a basic unit to be searched. Beyond that, tokens are implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: phrase
implementation-defined-item.description: A phrase is an ordered sequence of any number of tokens. Beyond that, phrases are implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: sentence
implementation-defined-item.description: A sentence is an ordered sequence of any number of tokens. Beyond that, sentences are implementation-defined. A tokenizer is not required to support sentences.

implementation-defined-item.name: paragraph
implementation-defined-item.description: A paragraph is an ordered sequence of any number of tokens. Beyond that, paragraphs are implementation-defined. A tokenizer is not required to support paragraphs.

implementation-defined-item.name: Scoring Expressions
implementation-defined-item.description: The set of expressions supported by the scoring algorithm is implementation-defined. If an expression not supported by the scoring algorithm is passed to the scoring algorithm, the result is implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: Matching
implementation-defined-item.description: Matching of the tokens in a query phrase to tokens in XDM is implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: Match Option Order
implementation-defined-item.description: The full order of the application of match options is implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: Language Option
implementation-defined-item.description: The "language" option influences tokenization, stemming, and stop words in an implementation-defined way. The "language" option MAY influence the behavior of other match options in an implementation-defined way. The set of valid language identifiers among the standardized set is implementation-defined. It is implementation-defined what additional language identifiers, if any, are valid. If an invalid language identifier is specified, then the behavior is implementation-defined. When an XQuery and XPath Full Text processor evaluates text in a document that is governed by an xml:lang attribute and the portion of the full-text query doing that evaluation contains an FTLanguageOption that specifies a different language from the language specified by the governing xml:lang attribute, the language-related behavior of that full-text query is implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: Thesaurus Option
implementation-defined-item.description: The set of relationships supported by an implementation is implementation-defined. If a query specifies thesaurus relationships or levels not supported by the thesaurus, the behavior is implementation-defined.

implementation-defined-item.name: Stemming Option
implementation-defined-item.description: It is implementation-defined what a stem of a token is. It is implementation-defined whether the stemming is based on an algorithm, dictionary, or mixed approach.

implementation-defined-item.name: StopWord Option
implementation-defined-item.description: Normally a stop word matches exactly one token, but there may be implementation-defined conditions, under which a stop word may match a different number of tokens. The "with default stop words" option specifies that an implementation-defined collection of stop words is used.

implementation-defined-item.name: Extension Option
implementation-defined-item.description: An extension option is a match option that acts in an implementation-defined way. Each implementation recognizes an implementation-defined set of namespace URIs used to denote extension options.

implementation-defined-item.name: Extension Selection
implementation-defined-item.description: An extension selection is a full-text selection whose semantics are implementation-defined. Each implementation recognizes an implementation-defined set of namespace URIs used to denote pragmas.

test-case.name: ftmatchoptions-q2
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: There can be multiple match options applied to an FTSelection, written in any order (although there are constraints on processing order). This query applies multiple match options in a random order.

test-case.name: ftmatchoptions-q3
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Only one match option from any given match option group may be applied to an FTWord or FTSelection. This query applies both with stemming and without stemming to test and returns an error.

test-case.name: ftmatchoptions-q4
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Only one match option from any given match option group may be applied to an FTWord or FTSelection. This query applies both case sensitive and case insensitive to Complete and returns an error.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q1
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Wildcard default query. Same as without wildcards. Find site without wildcards.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q2
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Without wildcard query containing a period. The period is a period, not an indicator. Depending on the tokenization find "site" or "site." ending in a period.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q3
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query containing a period. The period is an indicator. Find site. where the indicator is replaced by any one character.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q4
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard query containing a question mark not preceded by a period. There is no period, no indicator. Find site? where the question mark is a question mark.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q5
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Without wildcard query containing a period and a question mark. The period is a period. The question mark is a question mark. Depending on the tokenization find "site" or "site.?" where the period is a period and the question mark is a question mark.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q6
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query containing a period and a question mark. The period is an indicator. The question mark is a qualifier. Find site.? where the period and the question mark are replaced by zero or one characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q7
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query containing a period and a question mark. The period is an indicator. The question mark is a qualifier. Find completi.? where the period and the question mark are replaced by zero or one characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q8
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query containing a period and an asterisk. The period is an indicator. The asterisk is a qualifier. Find completi.* where the period and the asterisk are replaced by zero or more characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q9
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query containing a period and a plus sign. The period is an indicator. The plus sign is a qualifier. Find completi.+ where the period and the plus sign are replaced by one or more characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q10
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (infix) query containing a period and two numbers separated by a period enclosed in curly braces. The period is an indicator. The two numbers separated by a period enclosed in curly braces is a qualifier. Find a word that begins with u, ends with e, and has 3-4 characters between the u and the e.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q11
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (prefix) query containing a period and two numbers separated by a period enclosed in curly braces. The period is an indicator. The two numbers separated by a period enclosed in curly braces is a qualifier. Find a word that ends with proved, and has 0-2 beginning characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q12
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (prefix and suffix) query containing two indicators and two qualifiers. Find a word containing view with zero or more adidtional beginning characters and one or more ending characters.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q13
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query with a backslash preceding the period. Find specialist\. where the period is a period, not an indicator.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q14
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: With wildcard (suffix) query with a backslash preceding the question mark. Find next.\? where the period is a indicator and the question mark is a queston mark, not a qualifier.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q15

test-case.description: Bad syntax in wildcard range query -- 1 number not 2.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q16

test-case.description: Bad syntax in wildcard range query -- hyphen instead of comma.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q17
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Bad syntax in wildcard range query -- letters instead of numbers.

test-case.name: ft-3.4.2-expressions-q18

test-case.description: Wildcard query where the question mark does not immediately follow the indicator (.), so it is a searchable character not a qualifer.

test-case.name: ignore-queries-results-q4
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q4 Distance Query Ignoring Content of Descendant Elements Level by Level: Find all books with the word "workstation" near the word "lab". This query performs a level-by-level ignore. It ignores the content of descendant elements when querying the content of the parent element. Its descendant elements are promoted and then their content is queried. It differs from the ignore queries above because it queries the content of parent elements skipping over the descendant elements, then instead of stopping there it queries the content of descendent elements in isolation.

spec-citation.section-title: Q4 Distance Query Ignoring Content of Descendant Elements Level by Level

Its descendant elements are promoted and then their content is queried. This query uses synonyms supplied by the user, uses the unary not, nests a Boolean query and a phrase query within a window query, and ignores the tags and content of a descendant element.

Return the book title and publisher, if it has no authors. This query finds words and a phrase in different elements in different sub-trees. It also contains a conditional return.

spec-citation.section-title: Q5 Query on Different Elements in Different Sub-Trees with Conditional Return

GroupInfo.title: Use Case "XQUERY-XPATH-COMPOSABILITY"

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q1
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q1 Full-Text Query Constructing New Element: For books with "usability" in the title create a flat list of all title-author pairs, with each pair enclosed in a newly constructed element. This query finds a word in an element and returns the element and another wrapped in a new element.

spec-citation.section-title: Q1 Full-Text Query Constructing New Element

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q2
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q2 Full-Text Query Returning Count of Descendant Element Occurrences: Find all books with a chapter title on "usability tests". Return book title, chapter title, and the number of steps in chapters. This query finds words then returns among other elements a constructed element reporting the number of occurrences of a descendant element.

spec-citation.section-title: Q2 Full-Text Query Returning Count of Descendant Element Occurrences

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q3
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q3 Full-Text Query with Conditional Return: For each book with "usability" in the book title, return the book title and a second element. Return the book title and a third element if the second element does not exist. This query finds a word and contains a conditional return.

spec-citation.section-title: Q3 Full-Text Query with Conditional Return

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q4
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q4 Full-Text Query with Numeric Value Comparison: For each book with "usability" in the book title, return its book title and the round number of its suggested price if the price exceeds $25. This query finds a word and contains a conditional return based on a function on a numeric value.

spec-citation.section-title: Q4 Full-Text Query with Numeric Value Comparison

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q5
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q5 Full-Text Query with Character String Query: Find all introductions in books, published in "Washington, D.C.", which include listings for "rsums", "drafts", and "correspondence". This query finds words and a character string.

spec-citation.section-title: Q5 Full-Text Query with Character String Query

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q6
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q6 Full-Text Query with Conditional Return of Boolean Values: For each book on "usability" return the book title and a new has-publishers element with value true if the book has more than 1 publisher. Return the title and a new has-publishers element with value false if the book does not have more than one publisher. This query finds a word, then returns Boolean values based on the number of occurrences of an element.

spec-citation.section-title: Q6 Full-Text Query with Conditional Return of Boolean Values

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q7
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q7 Full-Text Query with Date Comparison and Element Occurrence Count: Find all books about conducting "usability tests" which have more than one author and are published after "2000". This query finds a phrase, counts the number of occurrences of an element, runs a greater than comparison on dates, and combines the results.

spec-citation.section-title: Q7 Full-Text Query with Date Comparison and Element Occurrence Count

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q8
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q8 Query with XPath Expression Within Full-Text Expression: Find all books published after "2001" which share a subject with the book with the short title "Usability Basics". This query finds words using an XPath expression to identify the words queried and looks for a publication date after the one specified.

spec-citation.section-title: Q8 Query with XPath Expression Within Full-Text Expression

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q9
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q9 Query Using an XQuery Expression to Determine the Number of Words Allowed in a Window: Find all books which discuss "successfully completing tasks". This query finds words within a window, allowing more words within the window depending on the number of chapters in the book.

spec-citation.section-title: Q9 Query Using an XQuery Expression to Determine the Number of Words Allowed in a Window

test-case.name: xquery-xpath-composability-queries-results-q9b
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q9 Query Using an XQuery Expression to Determine the Number of Words Allowed in a Window: Find all books which discuss "successfully completing tasks". This query finds words within a window, allowing more words within the window depending on the number of chapters in the book.

GroupInfo.title: Use Case "SCORE"
GroupInfo.description: Queries that must be written with score. Section 17.

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q1
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q1 Query Returning Scores: Find all books which mention "usability" in the title or the text. Return book titles and scores. This query performs a word query and returns scores, highest scores first. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q2
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q2 Query Returning Results with Top Scores: Find the best two books on "usability". This query performs a word query and returns only the results with the two top scores. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

spec-citation.section-title: Q2 Query Returning Results with Top Scores

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q3
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q3 Query Filtering on Scores: Find all books that focus on "usability". This query performs a word query and filters on scores.Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q3b
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q3 Query Filtering on Scores: Find all books that focus on "usability". This query performs a word query and filters on scores. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q4
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q4 Query Combining Score and XML Structure with a Conditional Return: Find all books with parts about "usability testing". This query finds books which contain parts about usability testing, returning entire books, but without part elements identified as irrelevant via score. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

spec-citation.section-title: Q4 Query Combining Score and XML Structure with a Conditional Return

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q5
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q5 Query Returning All Books Ordered by Score: Return all books, listing books with text on "software" first. This query performs a word query, returns all the documents in the database, and orders them returning those with found word first, those without last. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.

spec-citation.section-title: Q5 Query Returning All Books Ordered by Score

test-case.name: score-queries-results-q6
test-case.Creator: Full-Text Task Force
test-case.description: Q6 Query with Weight Declaration: Finds books which discuss "conducting usability tests" returning those which mention "measuring success" first. This query finds words using weighting on optional words to impact the scoring and sorting. Score is implementation-dependent, so any answer is acceptable, a few possible answers are provided.
